reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is hard to put down. Seldom a break in action, and the more you play the better you get at knowing when to control the zombies in your favor. The maps are well designed for small skirmishes, and there are no issues that plague some of the larger shooters like bad respawn points and lag.

Pros:
- It's fun: I can easily see myself putting many hours in to this game which is the most important benchmark to many
- Great constant action FPS, sort of like Q3A meets a modern shooter
- Tons of great stuff to unlock
- Great game for teamwork, especially on point capture maps. There is a very clear advantage to hunting with a teammate or two.
- Extremely smooth multiplayer, no lag

Cons:
- Somewhat dated graphics
- Takes a bit of time to begin unlocking the good stuff
- Voice acting is pretty tame
- In game UI or menu system is a tad confusing, would be nice to work with your unlocks immediately after a match
- In the game's current state you have to level up to use the different classes. Personal opinion, I think it would be more fun if everyone could run each class from the start and just use XP/$ to unlock weapons and upgrades

Overall
- Incredible amount of potential
- Highly addictive multiplayer, would happily sit here and play for hours
- Classic FPS meets modern in many ways
- As with all early access, needs some all around ironing out but there is no reason to think that won't happen
- Even at $19.99 for early access, you can get your money's worth. I'll likely put over 20 hours in to this game if not way more if it progresses well

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First thoughts about Moving Hazard.
I liked look of trailers. When got the game, I liked the game. Zombies are slow, as zombies should be. Action is fast, as action should be.

I've had really good time playing the hours I've used for now, and will continue playing more :)
Oh, to mention, I started playing some days before steam release.

Game is still beta, and just released into early access later today 10.3.2016. Game looks good, uses UE4, and has something new compared to other team vs team games.

Pros:
Zombies, slow zombies
Using of zombies as weapons / distraction
Guns are ok
Excellent map design
Devs are active!

Cons:
Can't say yet. Too early beta. Thanks to active devs, most things are likely to be changed / fixed pretty fast.

Conclusion:
Promising title, I really hope this will get and keep players in.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

+ Gameplay and sounds are authentic
+ Performance is much better than ARK: Survival Evolved
+ Cool upgrades like weapon attachments or increased armor protection
+ Single player!!
+ Active developer community
+ Works great with Steam controller
+ I hear Linux support and bots are coming

- Can't sprint while reloading
- No stamina gauge to find out when character will stop sprinting
- Jumping almost useless
- Animations are great but in some way look stiff. Bouncing walking animation is also a bit odd
- Plenty of servers, but they're all abandoned most of the time
- Pheremone grenades are useless in single player
- No difficulty options
- Lack of content; only four maps, one of which is a WIP
- Heavy's default primary weapon (M249) is incredibly inaccurate unless using the scope
- Only one secondary weapon for all classes: the Glock

Overall great value for what you're getting: basically the equivalent of a AAA title, albeit at a fraction of the cost, no microtransactions or DLC (well, hopefully these won't come later), multiplatform support, and active developers who actually listen to feedback from the community.

Playing against higher level guys, I feel as if I am not at a disadvantage which is huge for me as I take week long breaks from a game and only play a couple matches at a time so I dont rank up fast at all. I jumped right in and started getting top 2 players once I learned the mechanics. I like what they did with the zombies and being able to control them, matches do get hectic when people start throwing the grenades to control zombies. Overall this is a very good Early Access multiplayer game and I pray the devs stay on the right track with it. Can definitely turn into a very good game is they continue to add content and listen to feedback. I havent leveled up much so Im not sure how many weapons and if there is customizxation, so I cant respond on that .

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first glance it just looks like a Call of Duty clone with zombies thrown in but the combination of the two genres created something unexpected.  There is potential to be had here in more tactical play.  After about an hour of playing I was growing accustomed to moving with zombies and using them as camouflage as well as cover.  Baiting other players to chase you around a corner only to surprise them with some zombies you twisted for your own gain was fun.  I imagine that when the game is fully released this game will have a lot of potential on the competetive scene.

I write this review based on the Beta version alone and there were some issues I hope are addressed.  One of the first things I noticed was mouse movement.  It feels like there is some kind of mouse acceleration involved but there is not option in the menu to disable it.  Enabling Vsync sort of fixed the issue but I was having an incredibly hard time aiming normally.
Next is the guns, these may have been aesthetic choices but I had a hard time using them.  The aim down sight option is incredibly slow and takes about a second to actually pull the gun up to your face.  Next is that EVERY bullet has some kind of smoke tracer on it so you quickly blanket your screen in particle effects and have a hard time seeing your target.  On top of the particle effects, the onscreen NAV points that direct you to your next objective frequently blinded me from seen targets at range, players were literally hiding behind it, I would definitely recommend that you raise the icon above the intended marker instead.
This next one may or may not be minor but the spread on the guns felt strange, the more effective players resorted to holding the trigger rather then using burst fire.  Im not entirely sure if I was missing half my shots or maybe it takes nearly a whole magazine to take down opposing players.  I may just be spoiled on other FPS games though so I dont really know.
Lastly is sound, I dont know if my game was glitched or not but there was a distinct lack of sound in some areas.  I found myself dying quite a bit to zombies you had been nipping at my ankles for a distance because I couldnt hear them.

My list of notes to the devs is a bit long but that doesnt change that I feel this game is good and has lots of potential to become better after its Beta stage.  Im certainly looking foward to what its going to look like after its been out for a while.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Moving Hazard is a slow paced zombie multiplayer FPS implmenting zombie control with team based combat. By controling randomly placed points on the map, You gain points which is how you win your matches. You have an aray of weapons that includes grenades that manipulate the control of zombies to your advantage.

While playing a little bit over an hour, Competitivly. I have concluded that this is a pretty nice FPS with a nice change of space with the whole implication of zombies.

It really makes for some tatical game play while you dont wanna spray and pray due to being caught by a horde of zombies in the process of reloading.

I will say (Although i havent played enough to really conclude) that the health might need a little nerfing. I feel in the early stages before you unlock any guns, it takes about almost a full clip to kill someone (Although my aim might just be utter garbage).

And i also didnt see any indication of ammo pick ups? (But again i could just be blind?)

But here on planet Remulak, we enjoy this game.

7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not sure if I'll get a refund on this or not.

Played for some matches, and was disappointed.

I'm aware this is Early Acess but I got a bad feeling about this game.
I feel like I won't get the experience I was hoping for, even with updates and polish.

Pros :
- Good graphics
- Interesting zombie mechanics...
And that's about it.

Cons :
- Quite empty as of now, not alot of people playing it, and it's a shame for a PVP game
- The combat is slow paced and ennemy players feel bullet-spongey, might be a netcode issue.
- The netcode is really not optimal right now, 'blinking' players, getting stuck mid actions,
- The gunfeel is... not here, quite a shame for a shooter!
- Zombies aren't that much of a threat when you learn the mechanics.
- Terrible spawning system. Let's make you spawn infront of 2 ennemies, or right behind the guy who killed you, depending on your karma.
- Feels a bit COD-ish, but It's up to personnal preference.

In short, the feeling of the game isn't there, I would like to feel more into it, make the guns meatier, better animations, better sounds. Make it so I feel like I'm taking damage and in danger, not just look at my hp number go down and be like : Meh.

I might update this review, but for now, 20$ is way too much for what this game is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hate to say it, but in this games current state I do not recommend it. The reason why I hate to say it is because the game is great. The problem I have has nothing to do with the gameplay, it's a very interesting and intriguing concept, my problem starts with the community-or the fact that there is no community. That's right a Multiplayer FPS with NO community. There is usually 4 players on around 3 pm est but past 8pm it is hard to find anyone.
Not to mention the fact that it is 20 dollars, and simply not worth that at this point. Of course there are very few players, who's gonna pay 20 bucks for a game that nobody plays? Even 5 dollars would be too much. This game should be free, or maybe even one dollar at the moment. People will buy a free game they have never heard of before they buy a 20 dollar game they have never heard of.
I understand that the developers need money to fund the game, but you're hardly getting any sales for 20 dollars so why not discount?
The devs spent a whole bunch of money to have their own booth at pax east, and people really seemed to enjoy the game(I was one of them). However, i'm not surprised that it didn't bring in that many new players because the game is 20 dollars. It's could be a great game but it is poorly marketed.
I really like the concept of this game, and the graphics are nice and all that, but there's just not enough people playing it, and that won't change without a price drop.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Moving Hazards is a fresh slice from a stale pie. It's a team based FPS Zombie game that allows you to take control of zombie NPC's to go after other players. It adds a new aspect to a dying genre. I am still playing the game but absolutely love it so far.
